Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the accuracy of the GeNose machine by stating it has an accuracy of 99.9 percent, while the expert's verdict states that the accuracy is around 95 percent.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating in the claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the accuracy and speed of the GeNose machine.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the GeNose machine is a reliable alternative to other Covid-19 tests without providing sufficient evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that the GeNose machine is not an alternative to the PCR test, which is the recommended method for identifying Covid-19.
